definition:
If $\pi:E\to B$ is a bundle and $f:B'\to B$ is an arbitrary continuous
map, then there exists a pullback, or induced, bundle
$f^*(\pi):E'\to B'$, where $$E'=\{(e,b)\in E\times B'| f(b)=\pi(e)\},$$
and $f^*(\pi)$ is the restriction of the projection map to $B'$. There
is a natural bundle map from $f^*(\pi)$ to $\pi$ with the map $B'\to B$
given by $f$, and the map ${\varphi}:E'\to E$ given by the restriction
of projection.

If $\pi$ is locally trivial, a principal $G$-bundle, or a fiber bundle,
then $f^*(\pi)$ is as well. The pullback satisfies the following
universal property:

$$\xymatrix{ 
    &\ar[ddl]X\ar[ddr]\ar@{-->}[d]  &\\
    &\ar[dl]^{f^*{\pi}}E'\ar[dr]_{\varphi}&\\
B'\ar[dr]^f &           &E\ar[dl]_\pi\\
            &B          &       }$$

(i.e. given a diagram with the solid arrows, a map satisfying the dashed
arrow exists).
